title: 112_s549
content: The Act titled "Casting Light on EAJA Agency Records for Oversight Act of 2011" established the Equal Access to Justice Act in 1980 to allow small businesses, individuals, and public interest groups to recover attorney fees and costs. Despite statutory reporting requirements to Congress, the Department of Justice and the Administrative Conference of the United States stopped reporting on EAJA payments and administration in 1995, leading to a lack of Congressional oversight on the payments authorized by EAJA. SEC. 3. DATA COMPILATION, REPORTING, AND PUBLIC ACCESS. Section 504(c) of title 5, United States Code is amended to require the Attorney General to issue an annual report to Congress on fees and expenses awarded in the previous fiscal year under this section. The report will detail the number, nature, and amount of awards, justifications for exceeding award caps, and other relevant information for Congressional evaluation. The Attorney General is required to issue an annual report to Congress on fees and expenses awarded under Section 504(c) of title 5, United States Code. The report will include a searchable database, total awards given, total number of applications, party names, agency names, administrative law judges, application dispositions, hourly rates of attorneys and expert witnesses, and payments made under settlement agreements. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on fees and expenses awarded under Section 504(c) of title 5, United States Code. The report will detail the amount of fees and expenses awarded in the previous fiscal year, including the number, nature, and amount of awards, justification for awards exceeding the cap, and any other relevant information for evaluating the impact of such awards. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on fees and expenses awarded under Section 504(c) of title 5, United States Code. The report will detail the amount of fees and expenses awarded in the previous fiscal year, including key details such as party names, court details, judges involved, agency names, application dispositions, and hourly rates of attorneys and expert witnesses. The report will also cover payments made under settlement agreements. The Comptroller General will conduct an audit of the Equal Access to Justice Act for the years 1995 to the present within 30 days of this Act's enactment. The audit must be completed within 1 year, and a report on the findings will be submitted to Congress.
